customer_name: Keeper of the Wild Wildlife Rescue and Sanctuary
site_name: Keeper of the Wild Wildlife Rescue and Sanctuary

citations.narrative:
Multiple species that are housed at a different wildlife rehabilitation center were exhibited under the licensee’s authority
with their facility representatives. Per previous inspections conducted at this facility, the licensee stated this secondary
wildlife center has housed animals that were either receiving rehabilitation and/or preparing for release into the wild, but
none were used for regulated activity.
During the inspection today, the licensee stated one beaver, one opossum, and baby squirrels were exhibited at a local
fundraiser, but these animals are housed at the wildlife center or the home of a volunteer. While the licensee stated they
were under the impression the wildlife center was a part of their site that is currently licensed, the inspector reminded the
licensee only one site is associated with their USDA license, as requested and confirmed by the licensee on previous
inspections.
Animals used for regulated activity but housed at locations that have not been assessed and verified by USDA inspectors,
prevents the agency from knowing the conditions the animals are housed therein. This is required to determine the
facility’s compliance of the Animal Welfare Act and its regulations.
Facilities shall provide valid addresses for all locations, facilities, premises, or sites where animals, animal facilities,
equipment, and records are held, kept, or maintained.
Regulated activities cannot be conducted involving these secondary locations until a new site or prelicensing inspection
has been conducted.
Correct by April 23, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.1(a)(1)(iii) 
   
Requirements and application. 
Multiple species that are housed at a different wildlife rehabilitation center were exhibited under the licensee’s authority 
with their facility representatives. Per previous inspections conducted at this facility, the licensee stated this secondary 
wildlife center has housed animals that were either receiving rehabilitation and/or preparing for release into the wild, but 
none were used for regulated activity.  
During the inspection today, the licensee stated one beaver, one opossum, and baby squirrels were exhibited at a local 
fundraiser, but these animals are housed at the wildlife center or the home of a volunteer. While the licensee stated they 
were under the impression the wildlife center was a part of their site that is currently licensed, the inspector reminded the 
licensee only one site is associated with their USDA license, as requested and confirmed by the licensee on previous 
inspections.  
 
Animals used for regulated activity but housed at locations that have not been assessed and verified by USDA inspectors, 
prevents the agency from knowing the conditions the animals are housed therein. This is required to determine the 
facility’s compliance of the Animal Welfare Act and its regulations.  
 
Facilities shall provide valid addresses for all locations, facilities, premises, or sites where animals, animal facilities, 
equipment, and records are held, kept, or maintained.  
 
Regulated activities cannot be conducted involving these secondary locations until a new site or prelicensing inspection 
has been conducted. 
 
Correct by April 23, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
